newsitem.title: BANGLADESH: Bangladesh says bank system facing disaster.
newsitem.headline: Bangladesh says bank system facing disaster.

text.p: Bangladesh's central bank governor Lutfar Rahman Sarkar on Tuesday warned that the country's banking system was on the verge of collapse.

"The country's legal framework is very poor...The banks burdended with huge bad loans are facing legal problems. As a result the banking system is now on the verge of collapse," Sarkar told a meeting of bank lawyers.
He said Bangladesh's banking sector was burdened with 130 billion taka ($3 billion) in defaulted loans, with 50 billion alone owed by 137 individuals.
Sarkar blamed defaulters for the parlous state of the country's banking system.

He said they were taking advantage of the loopholes of law and called for strict new preventive measures, indlucing making it a criminal offense. At present is only against the civil code to default on a loan.

Khondker Ibrahim Khaled, managing director of state-owned Sonali Bank, the country's largest bank, said 40 percent of the loans came from private banks and less than 30 percent from the public sector banks.
The biggest problems were in the industrial sector, in particular in the leather industry.
Dhaka University professor of economics Mozaffar Ahmed said the government should immediately introduce criminal procedures as deterent against defaulting of bank loans.
Sohel Ahmed, managing director of Angel Fabrics, warned the problem threatened the country's reputation.
"The whole business community has been disgraced because of the deeds of few dishonest entrepreneurs." ($ = 43.55 Bangladesh Taka)
